measured_by: Implicit Association Measure (Sorting Paired Features task)
justification: In Study 1, participants used a sorting paired features task (SPF) to categorize word pairs reflecting psychological distance and speed, demonstrating both implicit and explicit associations between the two.

Study 2 assessed participants' choice of matching abstract concepts with slow music and concrete concepts with fast music, indicating experienced compatibility between psychological distance and speed.
In Study 3, participants rated the pace of life in distant versus close places, showing that psychologically distant places are perceived as having a slower pace of life.
Study 4 used participants' imagery and perceptions of behaviors performed slowly or quickly, revealing that slower behaviors are perceived as more imaginary or less real.

measured_by: Implicit Association Measure (Sorting Paired Features task)
justification: Study 5 employed the SPF task to explore associations between construal level and speed, finding that people explicitly associated abstract concepts with slowness.
Participants in Study 6 paired abstract words with slow music and concrete words with fast music, suggesting an experienced compatibility between construal level and speed.
Study 7 used NLP techniques to analyze the semantic proximity of words to the concepts of fast and slow, finding that concrete words are more associated with fast than slow.

Study 8 measured participants' perceptions of the speed of change with different action verbs (DAVs, IAVs, SVs, ADJs), finding an association between higher-level construals and slower perceived changes.
In Study 9, participants chose high-level or low-level action descriptions for behaviors imagined as slow or fast, indicating that slow stimuli are construed at a higher level.
Studies 10a and 10b used varying speeds of recorded messages to demonstrate that slow-paced speech is perceived as directed to more distant and larger audiences.
Study 11 explored the perception of a speaker's regulatory scope based on the speed of their speech, finding that slow speech signals an expansive regulatory scope.
